Wensley a Mu Yang a Yunfeng Lu b ⁎⁎ a Beijing Key Laboratory of Function Materials for Molecule & Structure Construction, School of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Science and Technology Beijing, Beijing 100083, People’s Republic of China Beijing Key Laboratory of Function Materials for Molecule & Structure Construction School of Materials Science and Engineering University of Science and Technology Beijing Beijing 100083 People’s Republic of China b Department of Materials Science and Engineering, University of California, Los Angeles, CA 90034, USA Department of Materials Science and Engineering University of California Los Angeles CA 90034 USA ⁎ Corresponding author. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author. Fax: +1 310 2064107. Graphical abstract The three-dimensional Zr-based metal-organic framework UiO-66-NH2 was functionalized with salicylaldehyde using a post-synthetic modification strategy. Then three kinds of copper (II) salts were successfully immobilized onto the surface of the modified UiO-66-NH2. The obtained UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2 catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic activity in the selective aerobic oxidation of various alcohols. The three-dimensional Zr-based metal-organic framework UiO-66-NH2 was functionalized with salicylaldehyde using a post-synthetic modification (PSM) strategy, and then three kinds of copper (II) salts were successfully immobilized onto the surface of the amino-functionalized Zr-MOF. The SEM and PXRD results showed that the morphology and structure of Zr-MOF were retained after multiple transformations. The obtained UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2 catalyst exhibited excellent activity for the selective aerobic oxidation of primary aromatic alcohols using molecular oxygen as the oxygen source. Furthermore, the UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2 catalyst showed a good cycle performance. Keywords Metal-organic frameworks Heterogeneous catalysis Aerobic oxidation Copper catalysis 1 Introduction The selective aerobic oxidation of alcohols to their corresponding carbonyl compounds is one of the most important chemical reactions [1]. Commercially available oxidants, such as 2-idoxybenzoic acid (IBX) [2], m-chloroperbenzoic acid (mCPBA) [3], organic peroxides [4], have shown quite high reactivity. However, these oxidants are highly toxic and hazardous. Molecular oxygen is a desirable oxidant due to its advantages of being inexpensive, safe and abundant [5]. Moreover, molecular oxygen reacts cleanly, forming only water as an environmentally friendly by-product [6,7]. Therefore, it is an attractive approach to use molecular oxygen for the oxidation of alcohols [8]. However, to employ oxygen as the oxidant, it is necessary to develop efficient catalysts which possess high activity and selectivity for selective aerobic oxidation of alcohols. The catalysis field has witnessed the development of the homogeneous copper catalysts in combination with 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-N-oxyl (TEMPO) for the selective aerobic oxidation of alcohols using O2 [9]. Semmelhack pioneered homogeneous copper catalysis work since 1984, in which he reported a CuCl/TEMPO system using molecular oxygen [10]. To date, the Cu/TEMPO system has been extensively studied by several research groups [11–14]. However, despite the high activity achieved by these homogeneous copper catalysts, they suffered from inherent problems in separation, deactivation and recycling [15]. To overcome these problems, the oxidation of alcohols using heterogeneous copper catalyst has been explored [16–18]. There are several issues, such as low catalytic efficiency, copper leaching, that need to be solved to make heterogeneous copper catalysis more practical [19]. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are one of the most important classes of porous materials [20–22]. Taking advantage of the high surface areas [23], unique topology and tunable properties [24], MOFs are highly useful in gas adsorption [25], catalysis [26] and other applications [27]. The post-synthetic modification (PSM) of MOFs is a viable route for synthesizing functionalized MOFs and generating multiple active sites [28–30]. Remarkably, the progress on MOF serving as a oxidation catalysts has been summarized in a comprehensive review on selective or chiral oxidation catalyst [31]. Very recently, Bogaerts et al. have reported efficient Mn-salen@MIL101(Al) catalyst for enantioselective epoxidation [32] and Cu2+@COMOC-4 and Mo@COMOC-4 catalyst for the aerobic oxidation of cyclohexene [33,34]. These heterogeneous catalysts exhibited a high catalytic activity and good recyclability, which indicated that MOFs can function as good catalyst supports. However, to the best of our knowledge, there was no report on immobilizing homogeneous copper salts on MOFs for the application of alcohol aerobic oxidation. It would be ideal to develop a Cu-derived MOF material to serve as an efficient alcohol aerobic oxidation catalyst. In this work, we fabricated a novel heterogeneous Cu(II)-MOF catalyst which can be achieved through the immobilization of three kinds of homogeneous copper (II) salts onto the surface of the amino-functionalized Zr-MOF (UiO-66-NH2). Three kinds of heterogeneous Cu(II)-MOF catalysts, UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2, UiO-66-Sal-Cu(NO3)2 and UiO-66-Sal-Cu(OAc)2 were evaluated for the selective aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol. The UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2 catalyst was chosen as the optimal catalyst due to its high yields of the desired aldehyde products. Furthermore, the catalytic activity of UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2 was maintained after five times recycles without loss of activity. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The zirconium chloride [ZrCl4, 98%], 2-amino terephthalic acid [NH2-BDC, 99%], salicylaldehyde [Sal, 99%], 2,2,6,6-tetramethyl-1-piperidinyloxy [TEMPO, 98%] were purchased from the Alfa Aesar. Copper chloride dihydrate [CuCl2·2H2O, 99%], copper nitrate trihydrate [Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, 99%], cupric acetate monohydrate [Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O, 99%] were purchased from Beijing Chemical Reagent Company. All the chemicals above were used without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of UiO-66-Sal crystals The UiO-66-NH2 crystals were prepared according to the literature procedure [35–37]. The prepared UiO-66-NH2 (1g) was dispersed in 30mL acetonitrile in a round-bottomed flask and stirred for 30min. Next, 5mmol salicylaldehyde was added to the mixture, and the sealed flask was transferred to an oil bath. The solution was stirred for 3 days at 40°C. When the obtained yellow solution was cooled to room temperature, the precipitate was isolated by centrifugation. The obtained products were washed with acetonitrile and anhydrous methanol three times. Finally, the obtained UiO-66-Sal was dried under vacuum oven at 80°C for 12h. 2.3 Preparation of UiO-66-Sal supported homogeneous Cu (II) salts The as-prepared UiO-66-Sal and copper (II) salts (0.6mmol) were dispersed into 15mL absolute ethanol, and the solution was then transferred to a sealed flask. The mixture was placed in the preheated oil bath at 40°C and stirred for 24h. At last, the obtained products were centrifuged, washed with absolute ethanol and dried under vacuum at 80°C for 12h. The obtained Cu (II)-MOF catalysts were named as UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2, UiO-66-Sal-Cu(NO3)2 and UiO-66-Sal-Cu(OAc)2 according to their copper (II) sources. 2.4 Typical catalytic procedure for selective aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol The catalytic reaction was carried out under the following conditions: heterogeneous copper (II) catalyst (4mol%), base (0.50mmol), TEMPO (0.25mmol), benzyl alcohol (0.50mmol) and CH3CN (2.5mL). The air in the above reaction system was evacuated and an oxygen balloon was supplied. The solution was centrifuged after stirring for 24h and the filtered liquid samples were analyzed via gas chromatography–mass spectrometry (Agilent 7890/5975C-GC/MSD) using nitrobenzene as the internal standard. 2.5 Catalyst recycling For the catalyst recycling tests, the reaction was performed with recovered catalyst under the same conditions as that used in the first run. The catalysts were filtered, washed with ethanol and reused for the next run. 2.6 Leaching test The UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2 catalyst was filtered via centrifuge after 8h reaction time, the conversion of benzyl alcohol and selectivity of benzaldehyde was tested by GC/MS using nitrobenzene as the internal standard. The mixture was further stirred for an additional 16h. After the reaction, the products were analyzed by GC/MS using nitrobenzene as the internal standard. 2.7 Characterization Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images of samples were obtained with a ZEISS SUPRA 55. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2 were revealed by a JEOL JSM-6700. The Langmuir surface area, pore volume and pore diameter were measured by an AUTOSORB-1C analyzer. The phase composition of the products was characterized by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD, Cu Kα radiation, λ =0.1542nm) via a M21X diffractometer. Fourier transform infrared spectra (FT-IR) were measured by a Nicolet 6700 spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was recorded using STA 449F3 instrument under nitrogen flow. The metal copper ions loading of the catalyst were analyzed using inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) on a Vavian 715-ES. 1H NMR was analyzed by Varian Unity Plus 400. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Zr-MOF catalyst The heterogeneous copper (II) catalyst was successfully formed by mixing copper (II) salts and amino-functionalized Zr-MOF in absolute ethanol. Initially, the porous UiO-66-NH2 was synthesized by previous reported work with ZrCl4 and NH2-BDC in DMF [35,36]. Then, the free amino groups were modified with salicylaldehyde to fabricate the UiO-66-Sal. Finally, the Cu2+ ions of the homogeneous copper salts were coordinated with UiO-66-Sal to form the heterogeneous copper (II) catalyst (Scheme 1 ). The amount of copper ions was analyzed by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES); the contents of copper in UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2, UiO-66-Sal-Cu(NO3)2 and UiO-66-Sal-Cu(OAc)2 were determined to be 5.25wt%, 4.08wt% and 3.27wt%, respectively. The modification ratio of UiO-66-NH2 using salicylaldehyde was determined by the proton nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) upon digestion of the UiO-66-NH2 and UiO-66-Sal in HF in d6-DMSO (Fig. 1 ). Digested UiO-66-NH2 shows two sets of doublet peaks and one singlet proton peak, which corresponds to the three aromatic protons. There are three new proton peaks after the salicylaldehyde modification of UiO-66-NH2 (Fig. 1b). This 1H NMR result confirmed the successful synthesis of UiO-66-Sal (Figs. 1 and S1) and provided the salicylaldehyde modification ratio of 16% using proton integration (Figs. S1 and S2). The UiO-66-NH2 with octahedral morphology was achieved by a simple hydrothermal method. All of the UiO-66-NH2 crystals are uniformly distributed and the sizes are 150–200nm (Fig. 2 a). The morphology of UiO-66-Sal is retained after salicylaldehyde treatment (Fig. 2b). Furthermore, the immobilization of copper chloride dihydrate on the surface of UiO-66-Sal have no impact on the morphology of UiO-66-Sal (Fig. 2c and d). The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms of UiO-66-NH2, UiO-66-Sal and UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2 are shown in Fig. 3 , and the corresponding data are summarized in Table 1 . It can be seen that the structures of each sample featured the type I isotherm. The Langmuir surface area of the UiO-66-NH2 was 1338m2/g with pore volume of 0.71cm3/g. After the salicylaldehyde modification, the Langmuir surface area decreased to 1040m2/g, while the pore volume decreased to 0.47cm3/g, which indicates occupation of the internal channels by iminophenol moieties in Zr-MOF structure [38]. The Langmuir surface area of UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2 catalyst decreases to 859m2/g when the copper moiety is introduced. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of UiO-66-NH2, UiO-66-Sal, UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2 and recycled UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2 are shown in Fig. 4 . The PXRD pattern of UiO-66-NH2 was in agreement with the reported UiO-66-NH2 (Fig. 4a) [39], which indicated that the desired material was obtained. The X-ray diffraction peaks of UiO-66-Sal and the UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2 are the same as the UiO-66-NH2 (Fig. 5 b and c), which suggested no structure alteration during salicylaldehyde modification or the incorporation of the CuCl2. In addition, the structure of UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2 catalyst remained intact after recycling five times (Fig. 5d). Fig. 5 shows the FTIR spectra of UiO-66-NH2, UiO-66-Sal and the UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2. For the sample of UiO-66-NH2 before post-synthetic modification (PSM) (Fig. 5a), the peaks in 3507cm−1 and 3392cm−1 were ascribed to the asymmetric and symmetric vibration of NH group [40]. After PSM of UiO-66-NH2, these two peaks disappeared (Fig. 5b) and the characteristic bands of UiO-66-Sal at 1569cm−1 and 1257cm−1 clearly increased due to the formation of CN (Fig. 5b) [34]. These changes in the FTIR spectra indicate the formation of the salicylideneimine [33]. The peaks of CuN or CuO at 630cm−1–510cm−1 are not found after Cu2+ ions were coordinated with UiO-66-Sal (Fig. 5c) [41], which should be due to that the characteristic bands of immobilized copper on the Zr-MOF were too weak to be observed. The thermal stability of UiO-66-NH2, UiO-66-Sal and the UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2 were confirmed by thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA). The TG curves of the UiO-66-Sal and UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2 indicate that they possess a similar thermal stability as the UiO-66-NH2 (Fig. S5). Two major weight loss stages were observed. The stage before 420°C was attributed to the loss of solvent molecules [42]. The second stage in the range of 420–570°C caused by the thermal decomposition of the MOFs [40]. 3.2 Catalytic activity of catalysts for selective aerobic oxidation of aromatic alcohols To evaluate the catalytic performance of the UiO-66-Sal-Cu(NO3)2, UiO-66-Sal-Cu(OAc)2, UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2 catalysts, the aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol was chosen as a model reaction and the results are summarized in Table 2 . No benzyl alcohol conversion was observed in the absence of the catalyst or just using the UiO-66-Sal support as catalyst (Table 2, entries 1 and 2). Meanwhile, the UiO-66-Sal-Cu(NO3)2 catalyst showed 83% conversion of the benzyl alcohol and 99% selectivity of the aldehyde product (Table 2, entry 3). It can be concluded that the cooper was responsible for the aerobic oxidation reaction. The UiO-66-Sal-Cu(OAc)2 catalyst gave 68% conversion and 99% selectivity when 4mol% catalyst was used (Table 2, entry 4). Furthermore, the UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2 catalyst gave 99% conversion and 99% selectivity using the same copper loading (Table 2, entry 5). A variety of solvents were tested using UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2 catalyst (Table 2, entries 5–8). Theacetonitrile (CH3CN), 1,4-dioxane, tetrahydrofuran (THF) and N, N′-dimethylformamide (DMF) solvents provided conversions to benzaldehyde of 99%, 82%, 78% and <5%, respectively. The solvent screen indicated that acetonitrile (CH3CN) was the most suitable solvent. Several bases were tested as well; sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3) results in the best catalytic performance with 99% conversion and 99% selectivity. The addition of strong base such as sodium hydroxide (NaOH) led to low conversion (Table 2, entry 9), because the strong base promoted decomposition of UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2 catalyst [35]. Futhermore, the UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2 catalyst did not function well in the presence of weak organic bases, such as triethylamine (Table 2, entry 10). Under the optimal reaction condition, the UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2 catalyst was further evaluated to prove its general application towards a variety of alcohol substrates. An aromatic alcohol with a para-electro-donating group, 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol, was converted to its corresponding aldehyde in 99% yield (Table 3 , entry 2). In contrast, 4-fluorobenzyl alcohol, which has a para-electron-withdrawing group, showed compromised catalytic activity (Table 3, entry 3). A heteroaromatic alcohol, 2-pyridinemethanol, provided the corresponding aldehyde in 99% yield (Table 3, entry 4). In addition, 3-phenyl-2-propene-1-ol was evaluated as an enol and 92% yield was achieved (Table 3, entry 5). Furthermore, 1-phenylethanol was tested as a typical secondary alcohol and much lower activity was observed (Table 3, entry 6). It can be concluded that the UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2 catalyst is the best copper heterogeneous catalyst among the catalysts screened for aerobic oxidation of primary aromatic alcohols. In order to confirm the catalytic nature of UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2, the leaching and recycling tests were performed (Fig. 6 ). The UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2 catalyst was isolated from the fluid and the supernatant liquid was stirred for another 16h at 60°C. The yield of benzaldehyde was retained at 53% after the filtration step, which indicated no leakage of the copper catalyst (Fig. 6). In addition, the catalyst maintained over 95% conversion of benzyl alcohol and 99% selectivity of benzaldehyde after five runs. The UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2 catalyst after five cycles was assessed by SEM, FTIR and TGA. The SEM image for UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2 catalyst after recycling five times showed that its morphology was retained (Fig. S3). The PXRD and FTIR spectrum of UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2 catalyst after recycling five times were similar to that of the fresh catalyst (Fig. S4), suggesting the structure and composition of UiO-66-NH2 was largely maintained. The TGA results showed that the fresh and recycled UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2 catalyst had the similar thermal stability (Fig. S6). 4 Conclusions In summary, three kinds of heterogeneous copper (II) catalysts were successfully synthesized employing a facile post-synthetic modification strategy of the amino-functionalized Zr-MOF (UiO-66-NH2), following by anchoring Cu2+ ions onto the UiO-66-Sal support. The characterization results showed that the morphology and structure of nanoscale Zr-MOF were retained after the multiple-step transformation. In addition, the selective aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol employing molecular oxygen as the oxidant was studied. The UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2 catalyst showed a high catalytic activity towards a variety of aromatic alcohols using NaHCO3 as the base in CH3CN solvent. The UiO-66-Sal-CuCl2 catalyst can be recycled five times without suffering from leaching problems.
